channel.title: My Watchlist News
channel.description: Aggregated news for my potential investments

item.title: [GOOG] Tech Weekly: Apple and Google do a deal, Glasses for the Blind
item.description:
STORY: From Apple and Google doing a deal to Glasses for the Blind, this is Tech Weekly.

:: Tech Weekly

Apple and Google-owner Alphabet have done a deal.

The iPhone maker will use Google's Gemini models for its revamped Siri coming later this year.

It deepens their alliance in the AI era and boosts Alphabet's position in the race against OpenAI.

Google's technology already drives much of Samsung's Galaxy AI.

But the Siri deal unlocks a massive market with Apple's base of more than two billion active devices.

And there's no sign Apple's dominance of global smartphones has let up.

The firm led the sector with a 20% share of the market last year - just ahead of Samsung.

Leading analyst Counterpoint Research said the firm saw solid demand in emerging and mid-sized markets.

And enjoyed strong sales of the iPhone 17 series.

The latest innovations in the tech sector were on show at the Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas.

.lumen showed off its so-called Glasses for the Blind.

The device goes on a person's head and acts in a similar way to a guide dog.

The firm said the glasses use haptics to help people with blindness go about daily life.

And employs AI to distinguish between safe and unsafe surfaces.

A new robotaxi design was unveiled in Vegas.

It's the product of a partnership between EV-maker Lucid, Uber and autonomous vehicle tech firm Nuro.

The car uses Nvidia's AI driving hardware, and can drive itself in certain conditions without a human using Nuro's autonomous tech.

David Salguero is Nuro's Head of Communications.

"We use an AI autonomy foundation model that basically learns as it goes along. So as we're driving, as we are testing, both on road and in simulations, it gets better and better at driving."

The group plans to launch robotaxi services in the San Francisco Bay Area later this year.

And AI wearables were on show in Vegas, too.

Some of the wearable tech included rings, jewelry, exoskeletons and glasses.

AI jewlery company Nirva showed products it claims can track your mood and record a journal of your day.

While tech firm ible demonstrated noise-cancelling headphones which they said can detect pollution and purify the air in front of your face.

item.title: [GOOG] The trillion-dollar IPOs investors are watching for in 2026
item.description: Listen and subscribe to Stocks In Translation on Apple Podcasts, Spotify, or wherever you find your favorite podcast.Investors are buzzing over potential $1 trillion tech IPOs in 2026, but which giants will come out on top? In this episode of Stocks in Translation, The Futurum Group Daniel Newman joins host Jared Blikre and Yahoo Finance Senior Reporter Brooke DiPalma to discuss the potential $1 trillion IPOs of OpenAI and SpaceX. Newman breaks down investor hype, competitive moats, and market risks, while also exploring Google (GOOG) Gemini‚Äôs AI gains, Apple's (AAPL) innovation gap, and how Amazon (AMZN) and Meta (META) are positioned to dominate AI in 2026.Check out the full episode here. Twice a week, Stocks In Translation cuts through the market mayhem, noisy numbers and hyperbole to give you the information you need to make the right trade for your portfolio. You can find more episodes here, or watch on your favorite streaming service. This post was written by Lauren Pokedoff

item.title: [IBM] From Nvidia to Salesforce: Where money is made in Enterprise AI
item.description: Listen and subscribe to Stocks In Translation on Apple Podcasts, Spotify, or wherever you find your favorite podcast. Forget chatbots, here's where AI is really going to make strides in 2026. In this episode of Stocks in Translation, The Futurum Group Daniel Newman joins host Jared Blikre and Yahoo Finance Senior Reporter Brooke DiPalma to break down where enterprise AI is really making money. Newman highlights top beneficiaries like Nvidia (NVDA), Salesforce (CRM), ServiceNow (NOW), Workday (WDAY), and IBM (IBM), and explains how AI is reshaping healthcare, defense, and SaaS, plus what investors should watch in 2026.Twice a week, Stocks In Translation cuts through the market mayhem, noisy numbers and hyperbole to give you the information you need to make the right trade for your portfolio. You can find more episodes here, or watch on your favorite streaming service. This post was written by Lauren Pokedoff

item.title: [LLY0.F] AbbVie Strikes a $100 Billion Deal With Trump. How the Drugmaker Will Dodge Tariffs.
item.description: AbbVie has agreed to cut some drug prices and invest $100 billion in the U.S. in exchange for an exemption from some tariffs. The pharma company said in a statement late Monday that it had struck a deal with the Trump administration to lower Medicaid prices and pour the money into U.S. research and development. AbbVie will also expand its direct-to-patient offerings of certain drugs on the government portal TrumpRx.

item.title: [GOOG] Google to develop, manufacture high-end smartphones in Vietnam, Nikkei Asia says
item.description: Google will start developing and manufacturing high-end smartphones ‚Äãin Vietnam this year, Nikkei ‚ÄåAsia reported on Tuesday, citing sources familiar with ‚Äåthe matter. Google already has a large network of suppliers in Vietnam that assemble its products, including Pixel smartphones. Google ‚Å†will begin new ‚Äåproduct introductions (NPI) for its Pixel, Pixel Pro, and Pixel Fold ‚Äçphones in Vietnam, with development of the lower-end Pixel A series remaining in ‚ÄãChina for now, the report said.

item.title: [GOOG] Investors back energy providers over big tech for 2026 AI bets, says BlackRock
item.description: BlackRock, the world's largest asset manager, still believes in the investment case ‚Äãfor artificial intelligence in the year ahead but ‚Äåwill be focusing on broader opportunities, it said on Tuesday. Investors seeking ‚Äåto play the AI theme into 2026 favour energy and infrastructure providers over Wall Street big tech, BlackRock said in its Investment Directions report, citing a recent investor ‚Å†survey it conducted. AI and ‚Äåbig tech dominated markets and world equity returns in 2025, but as the multitrillion-dollar ‚Äçrace between the likes of Microsoft, Meta and Alphabet to build new data centres generates worries about uncertain returns on capital ‚Äãand higher borrowing, investors were looking for new ‚Äåideas, the BlackRock survey showed.

item.title: [NVDA] Nvidia says no upfront payment needed for its H200 chips
item.description: Nvidia does not require upfront payment for H200 chips, a ‚Äãspokesperson for the U.S. chipmaker said in ‚Äåa statement to Reuters on Tuesday. The company said it "would ‚Äånever require customers to pay for products they do not receive", in a response to a Reuters story on January 8 about the company ‚Å†having imposed unusually ‚Äåstringent terms requiring full upfront payment from Chinese customers seeking its artificial intelligence ‚Äçchips. One source told Reuters that Nvidia's standard terms for Chinese clients have previously included advance payment requirements, ‚Äãbut they were sometimes allowed to place ‚Äåa deposit rather than make a full payment upfront.

item.title: [NVDA] SK Hynix to Build $13 Billion AI Memory Chip Packaging Plant
item.description: SK Hynix is the world‚Äôs leading supplier of high-bandwidth memory for Nvidia Corp.‚Äôs AI accelerators. Demand for HBM and other advanced memory chips has surged faster than anticipated as data center buildouts accelerate. Memory ‚Äî once treated as a commoditized component ‚Äî has become a bottleneck that directly limits how quickly data centers can bring new AI accelerators online.

item.title: [NVDA] SK Hynix to invest nearly $13 billion in chip packaging plant in South Korea
item.description: South Korea's SK Hynix said on Tuesday it has ‚Äãdecided to invest 19 trillion won ($12.90 billion) ‚Äåto build an advanced chip packaging plant in South ‚ÄåKorea to meet rising memory chip demand related to artificial intelligence. The chipmaker said in a statement that the construction of the new factory ‚Å†will begin in ‚ÄåApril, with completion targeted by the end of next year. SK Hynix said ‚Äçaccelerating global competition in AI is driving a sharp rise in demand for AI-focused memory, underscoring ‚Äãthe need to respond proactively to growing ‚Äådemand for high-bandwidth memory (HBM) chips.

Attending the event, Yahoo Finance Senior Reporter Brooke DiPalma sat down with KPMG US consumer & retail sector leader Duleep Rodrigo and PwC partner and US consumer markets industry leader Alison Furman to hear how retailers will be employing AI applications and how companies are expected to adjust to the adoption of GLP-1 weight-loss drugs and more active lifestyles by consumers. To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more&nbsp;Asking for a Trend.

item.title: [GOOG] Why Google's co-founders and Peter Thiel are exiting California
item.description: Big Tech elites, like Alphabet's (GOOG, GOOGL) Google co-founders Sergey Brin and Larry Page and Palantir's (PLTR) Peter Thiel, are hauling out of California to escape the state's billionaire tax act, which entails a one-time 5% tax on their wealth. If approved, the tax could affect individuals who were California residents at the year's start. Tusk Venture Partners founder and CEO Bradley Tusk outlines what the shift out of California signals about taxation and the sociopolitical dynamics at play. To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more Market Domination.

item.title: [GOOG] Google's corporate parent joins $4 trillion club as investors continue to bet on AI breakthroughs
item.description: Google parent Alphabet Inc. on Monday became the fourth Big Tech powerhouse to be valued at $4 trillion, a once seemingly unfathomable milestone that's become more like a rite of passage amid an artificial intelligence arms race. Alphabet reached the threshold just four months after Google dodged the U.S. government's attempt to break up its internet empire following a ruling last year that branded its ubiquitous search engine an illegal monopoly. In an effort to prevent further abuses, a federal judge overseeing the case ordered a shake-up that investors widely interpreted as a slap on the wrist, resulting in a 57% increase in Alphabet's stock price since then that has created an additional $1.4 trillion in shareholder wealth.

item.description: Retiring at 62 sounds doable when the house is paid off and there's a solid nest egg waiting. But for one Florida couple, even a well-prepped plan feels like it's riding a tightrope. Together, they've saved $690,000 in a Roth IRA and expect $1,800 a month in combined Social Security benefits. Their mortgage is gone, which lifts a major weight. But their biggest concern heading into retirement isn't housing ‚Äî it's healthcare. item.title: [LLY0.F] Nvidia Stock Closes Flat. The Chip Maker Is Launching an AI Lab with Eli Lilly.
item.description: Nvidia stock was languishing Monday despite news of a partnership with pharmaceutical company Eli Lilly The chip company‚Äôs investors remain focused progress on sales in China and the health of the wider artificial-intelligence sector. The stock is down 1.8% over the past month, as a flurry of robotics and autonomous-driving related announcements at the CES trade show, formerly known as the Consumer Electronics Show, failed to provide a boost. Nvidia said Monday that it was joining with Eli Lilly to fund an AI lab with an investment of up to $1 billion over five years to build models for biology and chemistry.

item.title: [GOOG] Meta plans to cut around 10% of employees in Reality Labs division, NYT reports
item.description: Meta plans to cut around 10% of the employees in its Reality Labs division who ‚Äãwork on products including the metaverse, the New York ‚ÄåTimes reported on Monday, citing three people with knowledge of the discussions. The cuts ‚Äåto Reality Labs, which has roughly 15,000 employees, could be announced as soon as Tuesday and are set to disproportionately affect those in the metaverse unit who work on virtual reality ‚Å†headsets and virtual social ‚Äånetworks, the report said. The metaverse had been a massive project spearheaded by CEO Mark Zuckerberg, who prioritized and ‚Äçspent heavily on the venture, only for the business to burn more than $60 billion since 2020.
